questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the office after a positive home pregnancy test. The patient lives in North Carolina with her spouse and a 3-year-old boy. Five weeks ago, the patient developed a rash, headache, and fever. The rash started from the wrist and spread to the ankles, trunk, palms, and soles. Her primary care physician suspected Rocky Mountain spotted fever and prescribed an antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking peptidyltransferase at the 50S ribosomal subunit. The patient was not aware that she was pregnant at that time. The last menstrual period was approximately 15 weeks ago. She is concerned about the potential side effects on her baby. Which is the most common finding in a child exposed to this antibiotic in utero?
questions.solution:
This patient was treated for Rocky Mountain spotted fever with chloramphenicol which has been associated with the development of gray baby syndrome in infants of mothers who are exposed to this drug during pregnancy.  

Chloramphenicol inhibits peptidyl transferase by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, thereby interfering with the binding of new amino acids to the nascent peptide chain. It is a bacteriostatic antibiotic. It is well absorbed perorally and parenterally and readily crosses the blood-brain barrier, so clients could use it to treat bacterial meningitis. Chloramphenicol is effective against some Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, Bacteroides species, and Rickettsia species. However, due to its severe toxicity, it is no longer used systemically in most countries with access to safer alternatives. The drug is sometimes used as a topical antimicrobial agent for bacterial conjunctivitis.  

Resistance to chloramphenicol occurs via plasmid-encoded acetyltransferase, which inactivates the drug. It also inhibits the hepatic cytochrome p450 and can accumulate various medications (e.g. warfarin). Adverse effects include dose-independent aplastic anemia and gray baby syndrome (in premature infants because they lack liver UDP-glucuronosyltransferase).  


Option Analysis

❌ Hearing loss:
Incorrect: Exposure to aminoglycosides in utero has been associated with CN VIII injury, leading to sensorineural hearing loss, vestibular instability, or ataxia. Aminoglycosides inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by the irreversible inhibition of initiation complex through binding the 30S subunit.
✅ Gray skin and vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Teeth staining:
Incorrect: Tetracycline use during pregnancy has been associated with enamel hypoplasia and yellow, gray, or brown discoloration of deciduous teeth in the infant. It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit and prevents aminoacyl-tRNA attachment.
❌ Neural tube defects:
Incorrect: Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole prevent folic acid synthesis by inhibiting bacterial dihydrofolate reductase and dihydropteroate synthase, respectively. Their use during the first trimester is associated with neural tube defects, while in the third trimester, it can cause kernicterus in the infant.
❌ Tremors and sweating:
Incorrect: In utero, exposure to opioids is associated with the development of neonatal abstinence syndrome in the infant, which can present with tremors, sweating, yawning, and feeding difficulties.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to his primary care physician after feeling a lump on his right testicle. The patient denies any associated pain. He has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a mobile, soft, round mass superior and posterior to the right testis. The nodule transilluminates when a penlight is held behind it. An ultrasound of the mass is performed and demonstrates posterior acoustic enhancement. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A spermatocele is a cystic structure filled with dead spermatozoa-containing fluid arising from the epididymis, rete testis, or efferent ductule.The etiology of spermatoceles is not known, although several mechanisms have been proposed including trauma, infection, or other inflammatory/autoimmune processes. It is hypothesized that the epididymal ducts become obstructed due to continual shedding of immature germ cells.

Most commonly, spermatoceles are incidental findings and do not cause symptoms. Palpation of the scrotum typically reveals a soft, round mass at the posterior and superior aspect of the testis. Similar to hydroceles, the cystic nature of the mass allows for transillumination. An ultrasound often reveals an anechoic or echolucent area with posterior acoustic enhancement. Spermatoceles do not typically require treatment, but they may require surgical excision due to pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Epididymis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pampiniform plexus:
Incorrect: Varicoceles are caused by impaired venous drainage and most commonly present with left-sided scrotal fullness and have the feel of a “bag of worms.”
❌ Tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele is an abnormal collection of serous fluid between the two layers (visceral and parietal) of the tunica vaginalis of the testis. A hydrocele causes more generalized scrotal swelling, whereas a spermatocele, as in this patient, causes a more defined, palpable lump associated with the testis.
❌ Spermatic cord:
Incorrect: Twisting of the spermatic cord can cause ischemia and subsequent testicular torsion. Testicular torsion presents with sudden intense pain in the testicles. The torsed testicle is often swollen and edematous, which makes it difficult to distinguish normal anatomy. This patient has a nontender, palpable mass that transilluminates, making another etiology more likely.
❌ Testis:
Incorrect: Palpable testicular nodules in a young adult male should raise suspicion for a testicular tumor. However, tumors do not transilluminate (since they do not allow the passage of light). In addition, the majority of testicular tumors are not mobile.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents to your office with a complaint of left-sided scrotal mass accompanied by dull-aching pain in the scrotal area. They first noticed a small swelling in the area two months ago, which gradually increased in size, and now their left scrotum feels heavy, especially when they stand. They state “Honestly, it feels a bit like a bag of worms.” Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a warm, non-tender, non-fluctuant left scrotal mass that does not transilluminate. The swelling increases in size with the Valsalva maneuver and disappears on lying down. Right scrotum and penis appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a left-sided scrotal mass that feels like a “bag of worms,” does not transilluminate, and increases in size with Valsalva; varicocele is the most likely diagnosis. Varicocele is defined as dilation of the pampiniform plexus, which is the venous drainage network of the testes.

Left-sided varicocele is more common due to drainage of the left gonadal vein into the left renal vein at a perpendicular angle. The effect is compounded by the compression of the left renal vein between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery (nutcracker effect), increasing the intravascular pressure in the left gonadal vein and the dilation of the pampiniform plexus. A right-sided varicocele should always raise suspicion for retroperitoneal pathology (e.g. renal cell carcinoma), especially if it is non-diminishing on recumbent position.

Affected patients may be asymptomatic, but they can present with soft, unilateral scrotal mass that does not transilluminate, dull-aching scrotal pain, and/or infertility. A bag-of-worms-like appearance is seen on scrotal examination.

In contrast, a hydrocele is thought to result from an imbalance of fluid secretion and reabsorption in the tunica vaginalis, leading to fluid accumulation around the testes and spermatic cord. Affected patients present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates well. Inflammatory conditions, like epididymitis, and torsion can precipitate the development of hydrocele.



Option Analysis

❌ Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis:
Incorrect: Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis causes epididymitis. Affected patients present with a gradual onset of scrotal pain (not a mass) that is accompanied by dysuria, urgency, or frequency. It is often preceded by urethral discharge in sexually active individuals. Common organisms are N. gonorrhea and E. coli.
❌ Fluid in the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Fluid in the tunica vaginalis results in the formation of a hydrocele. Affected patients usually present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates. This patient’s swelling did not transilluminate, making hydrocele less likely.
❌ Cystic dilation of epididymis:
Incorrect: Cystic dilation of the epididymis results in a spermatocele. It appears as a soft, round mass in the head of the epididymis that is located on the superior aspect of the testicles. Contrary to this patient’s presentation, a spermatocele does not enlarge with the Valsalva maneuver and is usually asymptomatic.
✅ Dilation of pampiniform plexus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neoplasia of left testes:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer is the most common cancer of young men and presents as a firm, non-tender nodule. It is discovered by the patient in most cases as a painless mass. Although similar to a varicocele in that it does not transilluminate, its size does not change with position as is observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A few hours ago, he was playing basketball with his friends when he first developed mild abdominal pain. The pain increased gradually, and since then, the patient had increasing nausea and three episodes of vomiting. The patient has had similar, milder episodes in the past that resolved with rest. The review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a soft, nontender, and nondistended abdomen. There is marked swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the right hemiscrotum. The pain is worsened when the right testis is elevated, and the scrotum does not transilluminate. Cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. Physical examination of the left hemiscrotum and testis is unremarkable. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute-onset severe abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting, in combination with diffuse right scrotal swelling, erythema, tenderness, a negative Prehn sign (pain that does not resolve with the elevation of testicles), and an absent cremasteric reflex; this presentation is consistent with testicular torsion, which occurs as a result of the twisting of the spermatic cord.

Testicular torsion is one of the most common causes of acute scrotal pain in infants and post pubertal individuals. It occurs due to the insufficient fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis, leading to hypermobility, which allows for the twisting of the testis around the spermatic cord, cutting off its blood supply. Testicular torsion may occur after an inciting event (e.g., trauma, vigorous physical activity) or spontaneously.

Testicular torsion typically presents as an acute onset of scrotal pain with a negative Prehn sign. Some patients may present with diffuse lower abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Physical examination shows a tender, enlarged, high-riding testes with its long axis oriented transversely instead of longitudinally due to the shortening of the spermatic cord (“bell clapper deformity”). Cremasteric reflex is typically absent.





Diagnosis is based on physical examination and doppler ultrasound for confirmation. Treatment includes surgical correction (orchiopexy) or manual detorsion if the surgery is not possible. Delay in detorsion by a few hours may lead to testicular nonviability and infertility. If the testis is not viable, orchiectomy should be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Twisting of the spermatic cord:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dilation of the pampiniform plexus:
Incorrect: Dilation of the pampiniform plexus results in a varicocele. It is more common on the left side, presents with dull abdominal pain that gets worse with standing, and feels like “a bag of worms” on physical examination. Cremasteric reflex is normal in cases of varicocele.
❌ Bacterial infiltration of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Acute epididymitis can result from the bacterial infiltration of the epididymis. It is characterized by localized testicular pain with tenderness and swelling on palpation of the affected epididymis (posterior testis). The pain is usually relieved by the elevation of testes (positive Prehn sign), unlike this patient. Dysuria and/or urethral discharge can also be present.
❌ Twisting of the appendix testis:
Incorrect: Testicular appendage torsion can present with acute onset testicular/abdominal pain. The swelling and tenderness, however, is localized to the head of the affected testes (unlike diffuse tenderness/swelling). Cremasteric reflex is typically present. A “blue dot” sign is often visible on physical examination, and the scrotal skin and testicles are usually normal-appearing and minimally tender.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele can result from an accumulation of fluid between the layers of tunica vaginalis due to a  persistently patent processus vaginalis. Although scrotal swelling is apparent on the affected side, it does not cause acute severe testicular pain, and it transilluminates well.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to his primary care physician’s office for evaluation of pain during sexual intercourse. Over the past several months, the patient has noticed worsening curvature to his penis and associated pain with erections. He does not have any history of trauma to the groin. The patient is a construction foreman and regularly works with large machinery. His past medical history includes a Dupuytren contracture treated with physical therapy. Physical examination demonstrates a curvature of the penis with a palpable nodule on the dorsal surface. Based on the anatomic image below, which of the following areas of the penis is contributing to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening abnormal curvature of the penis with associated erectile dysfunction. In conjunction with his history of Dupuytren contracture, he is likely suffering from Peyronie disease (PD). The pathophysiology of PD is not fully understood; however, it is thought to be initiated by microtrauma followed by local inflammation and collagen deposition in the tunica albuginea. PD is most common between the ages of 45–60 and is associated with conditions such as Dupuytren contracture, diabetes, and in patients following radical prostatectomy.

The most common findings of PD include penile pain, abnormal penile curvature, and indentation. Nearly 40–50% of patients present with concurrent erectile dysfunction, resulting in an increased risk of depression, relationship difficulties, and body dysmorphia. Diagnosis is clinical via patient history and penile examination, which demonstrates penile plaque(s) and penile curvature or deformity.

For patients with mild curvature and normal erectile function, observation is acceptable. If the curvature worsens or results in sexual dysfunction, medical or surgical management is advised. Initial medical management includes oral pentoxifylline, which decreases transforming growth factor (TGF) beta-1-mediated fibrosis and prevents deposition of collagen type I. In addition, the FDA approved Collagenase Clostridium Histolyticum (CCH) is the first and only agent to receive FDA approval for the treatment of PD. The collagenase produced by the bacteria Clostridium histolyticum degrades both types I and II collagen within the PD plaque.



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: The skin of the penis becomes affected in patients with ulcerative sexually transmitted infections including herpes simplex, syphilis, and haemophilus ducreyi. This patient presents with an abnormal curvature of the penis, suggesting a different diagnosis.
❌ B:
Incorrect: The corpus cavernosum is involved in the pathophysiology of vascular erectile dysfunction (ED). In ED due to arterial insufficiency, a decrease in oxygen tension in the corpus cavernosum results in decreased blood flow to the penis and a subsequent inability to maintain an erection.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: The corpus spongiosum contains the urethra. Damage to this structure can occur with penile fractures, which present with a “popping” sound, sudden-onset pain, rapid penile detumescence, penile ecchymosis, and difficulty urinating.
❌ E:
Incorrect: The urethra is often damaged in patients with blunt trauma or saddle injuries to the groin. Blood at the urethral meatus is indicative of urethral injury. Other clinical findings include difficulty voiding and perineal ecchymosis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe lower abdominal pain for the last 4 hours. He has not urinated for the past 24 hours and adds that he has had poor urine flow and difficulty initiating urination for the past 6 months; he also needs to get up multiple times throughout the night to urinate. He denies weight loss, dysuria, or urinary urgency. He has had seasonal allergies for the past week, for which he started taking diphenhydramine as needed. He does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a palpable mass in the suprapubic area. A symmetric, enlarged, non-tender prostate is palpated on digital rectal examination. Urinary catheter is placed with immediate collection of 700 mL of urine and relief of the patient’s symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with severe lower abdominal pain, inability to urinate (anuria), palpable suprapubic mass and evidence of excess urine in the bladder is consistent with acute urinary retention (AUR).   

Given the long-standing history of obstructive symptoms (poor urinary flow and hesitancy) in this patient, it most likely occurred secondary to untreated benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) which can lead to bladder outlet obstruction (BOO). BOO can be precipitated by over-the-counter medications, such as diphenhydramine, an antihistamine with anticholinergic activity (inhibiting bladder contraction) that is used to alleviate allergic symptoms (as in this patient). Diagnosis of AUR is made on bladder ultrasound or catheterization demonstrating retained urine in the bladder.  

Other complications of BPH include: 
  • Overflow incontinence: Occurs due to contraction of the enlarged prostate against the urethra, which impinges on the bladder neck, leading to incomplete emptying of the bladder that may progress to overflow incontinence over time. 
  • Urinary tract infection (UTI): The residual urine in the bladder may serve as a growth medium for pathogenic microorganisms, leading to UTI. 
  •  Chronic kidney disease: Hypertrophy of bladder musculature and dilation of the ureters, renal pelvis and calyces (hydronephrosis) occur in response to increased hydrostatic pressure at the bladder neck. If left untreated, it can lead to chronic kidney disease. 

Option Analysis

❌ Transitional cell carcinoma of bladder:
Incorrect: Bladder carcinoma usually manifests as hematuria in patients with a history of smoking or chemicals/carcinogen exposure from a workplace. Obstructive urinary symptoms (poor urine stream and hesitancy) are less common. An enlarged symmetric, non-tender prostate on DRE suggests an alternative diagnosis.
✅ Bladder outlet obstruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: UTI can present with poor urine flow and difficulty initiating urine. Bacteria can grow in stagnant urine in the bladder resulting in UTI. The findings of an enlarged symmetric, non-tender prostate on DRE and acute urinary retention are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
❌ Chronic abacterial prostatitis:
Incorrect: Chronic abacterial prostatitis usually manifests as chronic pelvic pain (perineal, testicular, suprapubic or penile) for at least three months in the absence of other identifiable cause. Obstructive urinary symptoms and an enlarged, symmetric, non-tender prostate on DRE are atypical.
❌ Prostate adenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Prostate adenocarcinoma can cause urinary symptoms by compressing or invading the urethra or bladder. Digital rectal examination, however, would reveal prostatic nodules, induration, and/or asymmetry.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of pain during urination, in addition to increased urinary frequency and chills. The symptoms have been present since yesterday. He denies any pelvic pain, myalgias or malaise. He has not been sexually active since his spouse died 2 years ago. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus and hypertension for 20 years. Current medications include metformin and amlodipine. Family history is significant for bladder cancer in his deceased father. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F), pulse is 100/minute, and blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. Digital rectal examination reveals a warm, tender, and boggy prostate. Complete blood profile shows hemoglobin 11 g/L and leukocytes 14,000/mm3. Urinalysis is as follows:  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Glucose  Negative 
 Blood  Negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  Positive 
 Nitrites  Positive 
 Leukocytes  10-12/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf 

What of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Proliferation of microorganisms in the prostate gland
Proliferation of microorganisms in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, chills and a warm, tender, and boggy prostate on digital rectal examination (DRE) in combination with pyuria (leukocytes >10/hpf) is consistent with the diagnosis of acute prostatitis.



Acute prostatitis results from the passage of foreign microorganisms in the prostate gland via the urethra or less commonly via direct inoculation, which typically occurs iatrogenically (e.g., transrectal prostate biopsy, catheterization, cystoscopy). Escherichia coli is the most common causative organism in older adults, followed by Proteus species and other Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, Enterobacter, and Serratia species). In contrast, Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are the most common pathogens in sexually active young adults.   

Complete blood count (CBC) reveals leukocytosis, and urinalysis shows pyuria, positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites (suggestive of E. coli). Urine gram stain and culture should be performed to identify the causative organism and to guide appropriate antibiotic therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Proliferation of microorganisms in the prostate gland:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperplasia of the prostate gland:
Incorrect: Hyperplasia of the periurethral zone of the prostate gland is seen in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It usually manifests with lower urinary tract symptoms (frequency, urgency, nocturia, dribbling) that develop gradually over time, as opposed to this patient’s acute presentation. Moreover, DRE typically reveals a non-tender, enlarged prostate, as opposed to a tender and boggy prostate.
❌ Proliferation of microorganisms in the urinary tract:
Incorrect: This answer is the etiology of a urinary tract infection (UTI). Although it can present with dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, and chills, the presence of a warm, tender, and boggy prostate on DRE would be atypical.
❌ Neoplastic proliferation of transitional cells:
Incorrect: Bladder cancer results from neoplastic proliferation of transitional cells and usually manifests as hematuria in patients with a history of smoking. Dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, chills and a tender prostate are inconsistent with the diagnosis.
❌ Inflammation of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Epididymitis is the inflammation of epididymis. It presents with acute scrotal pain, swelling and tenderness of the epididymis. A warm, tender and boggy prostate is suggestive of a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of acute right-sided scrotal pain with associated nausea and vomiting. The patient was playing football when he felt sudden pain following a tackle to the abdomen. The patient has tried over the counter analgesia and ice pack placement over the groin without relief of symptoms. He has had similar episodes of pain that self-resolved after 30 minutes. He has no significant past medical history and has received all age-appropriate vaccinations. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals an uncomfortable adolescent in significant pain. Examination reveals an edematous and erythematous right scrotum that does not transilluminate. Stroking of the right inner thigh does not result in elevation of the right testis. The pain is worsened with elevation of the scrotum. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis

questions.solution:
This adolescent male presents with acute right-sided scrotal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The physical examination demonstrates an absent cremasteric sign and negative Prehn sign, suggestive of testicular torsion -- a urologic emergency. The most common anatomic abnormality associated with this condition is known as the "bell clapper" deformity, wherein the testicle lacks its normal attachment to the tunica vaginalis. Ultimately, this deformity allows for increased mobility of the testes, transverse lie within the scrotum, and increased propensity towards ischemia of the spermatic cord.

The clinical features of testicular torsion include:

  •  History of intermittent testicular torsion: prior episodes of sudden, acute testicular pain that resolve without intervention 
  •  Sudden onset of acute, severe testicular pain  
  •  Swollen, tender, erythematous scrotum 
  •  High riding testis (moves to a higher scrotal position): this finding occurs due to shortening of the spermatic cord following torsion 
  •  Absent cremasteric reflex: normally, stroking of the inner thigh results in activation of the cremaster muscle and elevation of the ipsilateral testis. In testicular torsion, this reflex is almost always absent.
Several clues aid in the differentiation of testicular torsion and epididymitis. The Prehn sign is performed via elevation of the affected testis, and the maneuver results in mild relief of pain with epididymitis. Additionally, patients with epididymitis have an intact cremasteric reflex. In testicular torsion, any manipulation exacerbates the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Microbial infection of the epididymis:
Incorrect: Inflammation and infection of the epididymis results in epididymitis. In contrast to patients with testicular torsion, patients with epididymitis have a normal cremasteric reflex. Additionally, patients may experience pain relief with elevation of the testis (Prehn sign), whereas patients with testicular torsion experience pain with any testicular manipulation.
❌ Ischemia of herniated bowel:
Incorrect: This answer describes an incarcerated inguinal hernia. Physical examination of children with incarcerated inguinal hernias demonstrates an inguinal mass with extension into the scrotum. Incarcerated inguinal hernias are exquisitely tender and surrounded by edema and erythema of the overlying skin.
❌ Viral inflammation of the testis:
Incorrect: Viral inflammation of the testis can be seen in mumps, which is a common precipitant of  orchitis. Symptoms develop 4 to 8 days after parotitis but can also occur in the absence of this finding. However, this patient is fully vaccinated.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele is a collection of peritoneal fluid between the parietal and visceral layers of the tunica vaginalis. Hydroceles are a potential cause of testicular swelling, but they are painless. Physical examination also reveals transillumination, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the office because of weak urinary stream. He has been experiencing this for the past year, but it has been gradually worsening, and he now has to strain to urinate. He also complains of urinary frequency and urgency but denies incontinence or pain with micturition. He was recently treated for a presumed urinary tract infection with antibiotics for 2 weeks. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, smooth, firm, non-tender prostate with a rubbery texture. The rest of the examination is noncontributory. The most recent HbA1c 2 months ago was 5.6%. Urinalysis at this visit is as follows:  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Specific gravity  1.013 
 Glucose  Negative 
 Blood  Negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Nitrites  Negative 
 Leukocytes  1-2/hpf 
 Erythrocytes  1-2/hpf 

Prostate specific antigen is 5.5 ng/mL. Which of the following factors in the patient’s history is the strongest predisposing factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) refers to the benign enlargement of the prostate gland. The overall risk of developing BPH increases with age and is most common in men between the ages of 60 and 69 years.   

BPH is a histologic diagnosis that is characterized by nodular hyperplasia of stromal and epithelial cells in the periurethral zone of the prostate gland. As the prostatic cells proliferate in the periurethral zone, they impinge on the urethra, resulting in the lower urinary tract symptoms seen in patients. There is some evidence that the hyperplasia results from prostatic cell proliferation and impaired cell death mediated by androgens, mainly dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is produced from testosterone via 5α-reductase activity (which increases with age), and this theory explains why 5α-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride, are effective in management of BPH.  

The enlargement and increased smooth muscle tone lead to the development of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) over time which can be:

  •  Storage (or irritative) symptoms: Urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia and incontinence. 
  •  Voiding (or obstructive) symptoms: Weak urinary stream, straining to void, hesitancy, dribbling and splitting of the stream. 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Advanced age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cigarette smoking:
Incorrect: Cigarette smoking is associated with increased risk of transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder, which usually presents with gross or microscopic hematuria. Bladder cancer does not usually cause irritative symptoms such as frequency or urgency. 
❌ Recent urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Although an inadequately treated urinary infection may present with urinary frequency and urgency, this patient was treated with antibiotics for 2 weeks, and the urinalysis is normal.
❌ Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus may present with urinary frequency (polyuria) and, in the long-term, can lead to neurogenic bladder, which presents with continuous dribbling of urine and a sense of incomplete bladder emptying. This patient’s HbA1c is normal, indicating that the diabetes is well-controlled.
❌ Diuretic use:
Incorrect: Excessive diuretic use can sometimes cause urinary frequency but obstructive symptoms (straining, weak urinary stream) are not observed. A firm prostate with a smooth, rubbery texture would be atypical.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right-sided scrotal fullness of several weeks duration. The patient describes a dull, achy pain in his scrotum when standing for prolonged periods of time. He has noticed a 4.1-kg (9-lb) weight loss over the past three months and intermittent blood in his urine. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. He has a 45-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals temporal wasting and diffuse loss of muscle tone. Scrotal examination reveals a right-sided mass that feels like a “bag of worms” and does not decompress in the recumbent position. The left testicle is unremarkable. The scrotum does not transilluminate. Right-sided flank pain is reproduced with palpation. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Inadequate fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis
Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a right-sided varicocele (scrotal mass that feels like a “bag of worms”), as well as systemic symptoms (weight-loss, muscle wasting), and painless hematuria. Together these findings are suggestive of underlying renal cell carcinoma.

Varicoceles arise from impaired venous drainage. Veins in the pampiniform plexus slowly dilate and enlarge over time--resulting in an enlarged, edematous scrotum. It is important to note that varicoceles occur much more commonly on the left, due to suboptimal venous drainage; the left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein at a right angle, and it can be compressed between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery above the renal vein, thereby producing a "nutcracker effect." In contrast, a unilateral, right-sided varicocele is much rarer since the right gonadal vein empties directly into the inferior vena cava. When a right sided varicocele is observed it should immediately raise suspicion of an underlying compressive mass such as renal cell carcinoma.

Although many varicoceles may be asymptomatic, clinical features of symptomatic varicoceles include dull, aching, scrotal pain, typically worsened with standing and relieved by recumbency. Varicoceles that are not altered with changes in position suggest an underlying obstructive process (from thrombus or extrinsic masses). Palpation of the scrotum reveals an enlarged, tortuous dilation of the veins, often resembling a “bag of worms.”  

Option Analysis

✅ Renal cell carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inadequate fixation of the testis to the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Testicular torsion can occur in young males due to inadequate fixation of the lower pole of the testis to the tunica vaginalis. This patient’s chronic course of scrotal pain and hematuria suggests a different etiology.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: A hydrocele refers to a collection of peritoneal fluid between the parietal and visceral layers of the tunica vaginalis. Although hydrocele is a potential cause of testicular swelling, it is almost always painless. Also, physical examination typically reveals transillumination, making this etiology less likely.
❌ Bowel protrusion through the inguinal canal:
Incorrect: This answer describes an inguinal hernia. This patient’s constellation of symptoms (e.g., cachexia, right-sided varicocele) suggests a different etiology.
❌ Metastatic prostate cancer:
Incorrect: Metastatic prostate cancer can present with systemic signs (e.g., weight-loss, cachexia), as well as significant lower back pain. Although this patient is at increased risk due to his age, this unilateral, right-sided varicocele and painless hematuria suggests a different malignancy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of penile pain of six hours duration. Past medical history is significant for sickle cell disease. He does not use illicit drugs or take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates an engorged penis that is painful with manipulation. No urethral discharge is noted. The testicles are nontender, and the cremasteric reflex is intact. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Paralysis of cavernosal smooth muscle and impaired venous outflow
Fistula formation between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum
Excessive collagen deposition in the tunica albuginea
Testicular ischemia due to arterial inflow and venous outflow obstruction

questions.solution:
Priapism refers to a pathological penile erection in the absence of sexual arousal; it is a urological emergency.  Identifying priapism and prompt treatment is paramount, as delayed urologic care may result in permanent erectile dysfunction. There are two main types of priapism: ischemic and nonischemic:

  •  Ischemic (low-flow) priapism presents with a painful, rigid erection secondary to impaired relaxation and paralysis of cavernosal smooth muscle. This process results in a compartment syndrome of the penis, with resultant hypoxemia and acidemia in cavernosal tissue. 
  • Nonischemic (high-flow) priapism usually presents following genital trauma, without a painful or rigid erection. It occurs less commonly than ischemic priapism and results from a fistula between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum.
Ischemic priapism is far more common, and it occurs secondary to hypercoagulable states (e.g., sickle cell disease, thalassemia), neurologic diseases (e.g. spinal cord stenosis), metastatic disease (e.g., prostate cancer, bladder cancer) and medications that relax smooth muscles (e.g., trazodone, prostaglandins, hydralazine). The precise pathophysiology of priapism secondary to sickle cell disease is not fully understood; however, is thought to be due to a combination vaso-occlusion and a regulatory defect in the nitric oxide pathway.

Enhancement of venous outflow is the goal in management of ischemic priapism, and intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine is commonly performed. The alpha-agonist effects of phenylephrine contract the cavernosal smooth muscle, allowing for reentry of oxygenated blood through the penis. In addition, aspiration of static cavernosal blood is performed to further promote venous outflow and detumescence.

Option Analysis

✅ Paralysis of cavernosal smooth muscle and impaired venous outflow:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fistula formation between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum:
Incorrect: Nonischemic priapism (also known as high-flow) occurs less commonly than ischemic priapism and is usually the result of a fistula between the cavernosal artery and corpus cavernosum. Nonischemic priapism is more commonly related to penile trauma than underlying sickle cell disease.
❌ Excessive collagen deposition in the tunica albuginea:
Incorrect: Peyronie disease is a condition caused by microtrauma and subsequent collagen and scar formation in the tunica albuginea. Patients present with a visibly curved penis, penile pain, and erectile dysfunction.
❌ Anterior urethral injury:
Incorrect: Anterior urethral injury can be seen in patients with blunt trauma or saddle injuries to the perineum. Blood at the urethral meatus, difficulty voiding, and perineal/genital ecchymosis are suggestive of urethral injury.
❌ Testicular ischemia due to arterial inflow and venous outflow obstruction:
Incorrect: Testicular torsion occurs when the testis torses (twists) on the spermatic cord, resulting in ischemia from reduced arterial inflow and venous outflow obstruction. Testicular torsion typically results in sudden-onset, acute, unilateral testicular pain with an absent cremasteric reflex.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of scrotal fullness of several weeks duration.The patient endorses an associated dull, achy pain in his scrotum when standing for prolonged periods that is relieved with lying flat. There are no acute episodes of sudden pain. He has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a left-sided scrotal mass that feels like a “bag of worms'' and decompresses with recumbency. The right scrotum is unremarkable. The scrotum does not transilluminate. Which of the following is the most likely complication of this patient's disease if left untreated?

choices.text: Oxidative stress-mediated apoptosis of germ cells
Torsion of the spermatic cord and ischemia of the testis
Incarceration and ischemia of trapped bowel loops

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of an enlarged left hemiscrotum, dull, achy pain, and improved testicular swelling with recumbency, consistent with a left-sided varicocele. The pathophysiology of this condition occurs secondary to impaired venous drainage. Veins in the pampiniform plexus slowly dilate and enlarge due to impaired outflow; this condition occurs much more commonly on the left. The left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein at a right angle, and it can be compressed between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery above the renal vein, thereby producing a "nutcracker effect." In contrast, a unilateral, right-sided varicocele is much rarer, since the right gonadal vein empties directly into the inferior vena cava.

Varicoceles are the most common cause of male infertility. A major function of the testicular veins is to draw heat centrally. Impaired venous drainage can cause the testicles to overheat and impair spermatogenesis. This complication can result in decreased sperm quantity and quality, as well as lower testosterone levels. Heat stress has shown to be closely associated with oxidative stress, with subsequent apoptosis of germ cells; this complication can also be seen clinically as testicular atrophy secondary to loss of germ cell mass.

Varicoceles can be diagnosed with an ultrasound which will demonstrate reversal of blood flow in the pampiniform plexus. Treatment is indicated if the varicocele is associated with discomfort/pain, testicular atrophy, and infertility.  

Option Analysis

✅ Oxidative stress-mediated apoptosis of germ cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Malignant proliferation of germ cells:
Incorrect: Cryptorchidism is a significant risk factor for the development of testicular cancer--likely due to a combination of intraabdominal temperature elevation and hormonal imbalances. Current studies demonstrate that although varicoceles cause elevated intrascrotal temperatures, they are not conclusively linked to increased incidence of malignant transformation.
❌ Torsion of the spermatic cord and ischemia of the testis:
Incorrect: Testicular torsion can be preceded by intermittent torsions--which are episodes of sudden onset severe testicular pain that resolve without intervention. This patient’s chronic, dull and achy pain is suggestive of a different underlying etiology.
❌ Incarceration and ischemia of trapped bowel loops:
Incorrect: This answer describes a strangulated inguinal hernia. Physical examination usually reveals an inguinal mass that is worsened with increased abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, Valsalva maneuver) and may extend to the scrotum. The mass typically is tender and surrounded by edema with erythema of the overlying skin. This patient’s symptoms (e.g., dull, achy pain, relieved by recumbency) suggests a different etiology.
❌ Metastatic renal cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: A unilateral, right-sided varicocele is much rarer, since the right gonadal vein empties directly  into the IVC. The presence of a right sided varicocele should immediately raise suspicion of an underlying renal mass such as renal cell carcinoma. This patient is young, and this varicocele is left-sided, thus making this etiology and complication less likely.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the office because of perineal pain for the past 4 months. He states that the pain is dull, constant and has been interfering with daily activities. He also reports mild pain during urination but denies urinary frequency, urgency or straining. Past medical history is significant for migraine headaches. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination including digital rectal examination is normal. There is no suprapubic pain on palpation. Urinalysis shows no abnormality. Expressed prostatic secretion shows 2 leukocytes/hpf, but culture does not grow a pathogenic organism. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chronic perineal pain, mild dysuria and normal physical examination and laboratory evaluation is consistent with chronic abacterial prostatitis, a type of chronic prostatitis.    

Chronic prostatitis can be bacterial or abacterial. Chronic bacterial prostatitis usually occurs secondary to previous urinary tract infection (UTI) whereby bacteria migrate from the urinary tract into the prostate through intraprostatic reflux of urine. It can also sometimes present as a complication of acute prostatitis following incomplete treatment.    

Chronic abacterial prostatitis, also known as chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS), is defined as chronic pelvic pain (perineal, testicular, suprapubic or penile) for at least three months in the absence of another identifiable cause that is often associated with urinary symptoms and/or sexual dysfunction. It may be due to inflammation secondary to trauma or due to normal prostate flora, autoimmunity, neurogenic pain, and the interplay of somatic and psychological factors. Digital rectal examination (DRE) shows a mildly tender prostate, though it is not always present. Diagnosis is aided by urinalysis and expressed prostatic secretions.



Option Analysis

❌ Benign prostatic hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) usually manifests with lower urinary tract symptoms like frequency, urgency, nocturia, dribbling, and a non-tender, enlarged prostate on DRE. A normal DRE and the absence of lower urinary tract symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.   
❌ Acute prostatitis:
Incorrect: Acute prostatitis usually presents with sudden-onset dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, chills and a warm, tender and boggy prostate on DRE. This patient’s normal DRE and urinalysis, a sterile culture of prostatic secretions, and chronic symptoms make this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Chronic bacterial prostatitis:
Incorrect: Although chronic bacterial prostatitis can present with chronic perineal pain and dysuria, prostatic secretions containing <12 leukocytes/hpf and no growth of organisms on culture are atypical.
✅ Chronic abacterial prostatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cystitis:
Incorrect: Cystitis usually presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic pain. Urinalysis often reveals pyuria and positive leukocyte esterase and/or nitrites.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to a urology clinic for evaluation of an ulcerated penile lesion. The lesion has been present on the glans of the penis for eight weeks. He completed a course of penicillin, doxycycline, and fluconazole without improvement of the lesion. Past medical history includes psoriasis treated with topical corticosteroids. The patient immigrated from Sri Lanka in his twenties and is unsure of his vaccination status. He has had multiple sexual partners and occasionally uses condoms for protection. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a circumcised penis with a 2-cm painless ulcer noted on the dorsal aspect of the glans without surrounding swelling or erythema. Several verrucous, cauliflower-like growths are also noted at the base of the penis. Bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor predisposing this patient to the development of this ulcerative lesion?
questions.solution:
This middle-aged man presents for evaluation of a chronic penile ulcer resistant to antibiotic therapy. The patient also has a history of multiple sexual partners, marked inguinal lymphadenopathy, and condyloma accuminata, suggesting underlying squamous cell carcinoma of the penis.

There are several risk factors for the development of penile cancer, including:

  •  Phimosis  
  •  History of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), especially human papillomavirus (HPV) and HIV 
  •  Tobacco use 
  •  Lichen sclerosus 
  • Poor hygiene
HPV DNA is identified in 30-50% of all penile carcinomas. Further evidence of HPV infection includes the presence of condyloma accuminata (genital warts), which are soft papillomatous growths associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Although these lesions rarely undergo malignant transformation, immunosuppression can augment this process. Overall, HPV-associated squamous cell carcinoma of the penis is most associated with infection from subtypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, and 39.  

Option Analysis

✅ Infection with a DNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection with a spirochete:
Incorrect: Bacterial infection (such as with Treponema pallidum) can result in a painless chancre on the penis. Over time, the papule can ulcerate, resulting in a 1 to 2 cm ulcer with raised, indurated margins. This patient was treated for underlying syphilis with penicillin.
❌ Candida infection:
Incorrect: Penile balanitis can be caused by fungal infections (e.g. Candida). Symptoms include pain, tenderness, or pruritus with erythematous lesions on the glans and/or the foreskin. This patient received adequate antifungal therapy and also has verrucous growths and inguinal lymphadenopathy, making another etiology more likely.
❌ History of circumcision:
Incorrect: Circumcision is protective against the development of penile cancers, as it eliminates the closed preputial environment that induces chronic inflammation.
❌ History of psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is not a known risk factor for the development of squamous cell carcinoma of the penis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for evaluation of an itchy rash on his penis. The rash has been present on the glans of the penis for seven weeks. The patient immigrated from Argentina in his twenties and is unsure of his vaccination status. He has had multiple sexual partners and occasionally uses condoms for protection. Physical examination reveals an uncircumcised penis. A 2-cm velvety, red, well-marginated, painless ulcer is noted on the glans penis. No other penile deformities are observed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This uncircumcised male presents for evaluation of an erythematous painless ulcer on the glans penis. Given the location and character of this lesion, he likely has erythroplasia of Queyrat--a premalignant lesion caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).

Premalignant penile lesions include Bowen disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat, and Bowenoid papulosis, which are associated with the high-risk HPV subtypes 16 and 18. Bowen disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat, and Bowenoid papulosis are clinical variants of carcinoma in situ (CIS) and can be differentiated based on appearnace and location:

  •  Bowen disease presents as red, shiny, pigmented patches or plaques on the shaft of the penis or the scrotum. 
  •  Erythroplasia of Queyrat presents as erythroplakia on the glans/prepuce; only the location distinguishes Bowen disease from erythroplasia of Queyrat. 
  •  Bowenoid papulosis presents as multiple warty-like lesions, usually on the penile shaft, which are often pigmented.

Option Analysis

✅ Erythroplasia of Queyrat:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bowen disease:
Incorrect: Bowen disease is characterized by erythroplakia on the shaft of the penis or scrotum. The difference between Bowen disease and erythroplasia of Queyrat is the location--erythroplasia of Queyrat occurs on the glans penis, whereas Bowen disease occurs on the shaft of the penis.
❌ Bowenoid papulosis:
Incorrect: Bowenoid papulosis results in multiple papular lesions on the shaft of the penis. It is most often seen in younger males and is characterized by multiple slightly elevated papules that are red to violet in color.
❌ Lichen sclerosus:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosus is characterized by white atrophic plaques on the glans and prepuce. These plaques grow and coalesce into a sclerotic mass with resultant adhesions, phimosis, and meatal stenosis. Lichen sclerosus is most commonly observed in uncircumcised males.
❌ Peyronie disease:
Incorrect: Peyronie disease is a condition caused by microtrauma and subsequent collagen and scar formation in the tunica albuginea. Patients present with a curved penis, penile pain, and erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the office after an episode of lightheadedness. He experienced this episode last night when he got up from a chair to go to the kitchen and suddenly felt like he was going to fall, but he was able to grab the couch for balance. He does not recall experiencing similar symptoms in the past. He did not lose consciousness or hit his head. The patient was recently started on a new medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia. Other medications include metformin for type 2 diabetes mellitus and ibuprofen for osteoarthritis. Blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg and pulse is 75/min while supine and 80/62 mmHg and 89/min while standing. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged non-tender prostate. Electrocardiogram shows a normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Orthostatic hypotension is common in elderly patients and mostly occurs due to sudden postural change causing a rapid decrease in preload. Normally, the fall in blood pressure provokes a baroreceptor reflex, resulting in increased vascular resistance via activation of peripheral vascular alpha-1 receptors and decreased parasympathetic outflow. This response, however, can be impaired due to several causes. This patient’s episode of lightheadedness and orthostatic changes in blood pressure are consistent with orthostatic hypotension most likely due to his advanced age and recent initiation of terazosin, an alpha-1 receptor antagonist for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).  

Common medications used in the treatment of BPH are as follows:  

 

Patients who fail to improve on medical therapy for 12 to 24 months are considered for surgical intervention, which includes transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) or prostatectomy to remove part or the entire prostate.  

Option Analysis

❌ Finasteride:
Incorrect: Finasteride is a 5α-reductase inhibitor that acts by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT). Although it is sometimes used to slow the progression of BPH, its common side effects include decreased libido and erectile dysfunction. It does not act on peripheral blood vessels.
✅ Terazosin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tolterodine:
Incorrect: Tolterodine is an anticholinergic agent. It acts on bladder and prostate muscles to decrease contractility and is sometimes used to treat lower urinary tract symptoms seen in overactive bladder. Common side effects include dry mouth, urinary retention, mydriasis and constipation. Orthostatic hypertension is rare. 
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) that acts by inhibiting cyclooxygenase, thereby preventing the conversion of arachidonic acid to various inflammatory mediators (e.g., prostaglandins, prostacyclin, thromboxane). Common side effects include dyspepsia, gastrointestinal ulcers, ototoxicity and allergic reactions, but not orthostatic hypotension, as observed in this patient.
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Metformin inhibits gluconeogenesis to decrease hepatic glucose output. It also increases insulin sensitivity in the body. Common side effects include lactic acidosis, abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhea. It may cause dizziness secondary to hypoglycemia but not orthostatic hypotension, as observed in this patient.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to his cardiologist for a follow-up appointment after being prescribed a new medication several weeks ago. Symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity swelling have improved. However, he has noticed that his chest wall has been more tender than usual. Moreover, the patient has had difficulty achieving an erection. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for bilateral gynecomastia. Which medications were most likely prescribed to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of heart failure, presents several weeks after initiating a new medication. His history and physical examination demonstrate gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction, which are concerning for antiandrogenic side effects. Of the medications listed, only spironolactone carries this side effect profile.    

Spironolactone works primarily as a competitive aldosterone receptor antagonist in the cortical collecting tubule. It induces diuresis while preserving plasma potassium levels. In addition to this mechanism, spironolactone carries moderate anti-androgen effects via the blockade of androgen receptors. This blockade can result in gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido, and mood changes in men. When used in women, anti-androgen effects can result in breast enlargement and menstrual disturbances.  

Despite these side effects, spironolactone’s anti-androgenic effects make it a useful medication in treating several clinical conditions and heart failure. It is often used to treat acne vulgaris and hirsutism in women and acts as hormone therapy for transgender females. 

Option Analysis

✅ Spironolactone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic often prescribed for treating heart failure and hypervolemia. It does not carry anti-androgenic properties that would cause gynecomastia and erectile dysfunction.
❌ Carvedilol:
Incorrect: ꞵ-blockers are often employed in treating heart failure and can cause depression. However, they are not known to cause gynecomastia. 
❌ Milrinone:
Incorrect: Milrinone is another medication often used in the treatment of heart failure and pulmonary hypertension that works via activation of protein kinase A and inhibition of PDE3, which leads to increased inotropy and chronotropy. 
❌ Eplerenone :
Incorrect: Eplerenone, like spironolactone, works as a competitive aldosterone antagonist. However, it lacks the anti-androgenic properties associated with spironolactone.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate nocturia and difficulty urinating. The patient has had these symptoms for a year, and it has been worsening. Currently, the patient wakes up three times a night to urinate. In addition, the patient noticed that it takes longer than usual for him to start urinating. Digital rectal examination reveals symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodularity. Urinalysis is within normal limits, and urinary culture is negative. The physician decided to start the patient on tamsulosin and finasteride. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of finasteride?

choices.text: Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone
Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland
Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra
Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum

questions.solution:
This patient with urinary flow obstruction (urinary hesitancy and straining) and irritative symptoms (frequency and nocturia) most likely have benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It is a common disease in the elderly that occurs due to overgrowth of the prostate gland, leading to obstruction of the prostatic urethra and urinary symptoms. Finasteride is sometimes used in the treatment of BPH.

Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is an androgen that stimulates the growth of the prostate gland and is also associated with male pattern hair loss (i.e. androgenetic alopecia). Finasteride inhibits the conversion of testosterone to DHT by blocking the action of enzyme 5-alpha reductase, leading to decreased growth and, ultimately, shrinkage of the prostate gland, thereby reducing the blockage on the urethra. However, these effects usually take months to develop; therefore, finasteride's effects will only be seen after continuous use for a long period. Finasteride can also be used in the treatment of androgenetic alopecia.

Side effects of finasteride are common and include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and gynecomastia. In addition, some patients may also experience orthostatic hypotension. Finally, patients taking finasteride at high doses may develop infertility, which in severe cases, may be irreversible.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland:
Incorrect: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist usually used in metastatic prostate cancer. It is not frequently used in benign prostatic hyperplasia because of its feminization effects. Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor.  
❌ Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra:
Incorrect: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonists (e.g. tamsulosin) are the first-line treatment of BPH, and they work via relaxing the smooth muscles in the prostatic urethra and prostate glands, thereby resolving the urinary blockage. However, finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, not an alpha-1 receptor antagonist.  
❌ Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum:
Incorrect: Certain medications inhibit testosterone synthesis (e.g. ketoconazole). However, finasteride does not inhibit testosterone synthesis and sometimes increased testosterone levels can be seen in patients taking finasteride.  
❌ Inhibits the synthesis of gonadotropins:
Incorrect: Use of Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (e.g. Leuprolide) can lead to suppression of production of gonadotropins, leading to decreased testosterone production. However, finasteride does not inhibit the synthesis of gonadotropins.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the physician to discuss his hair loss. The patient first noticed the hair loss two years ago, which has progressed since then. His father and brother also had early hair loss. Physical examination reveals hair loss consistent with male pattern hair loss (i.e. androgenetic alopecia). The physician decided to start the patient on finasteride in addition to a ketoconazole shampoo. Which of the following best describes ketoconazole's role in treating this patient’s hair loss?

choices.text: Decreased testosterone synthesis by inhibiting 17,20 lyase enzyme
Decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by inhibiting the 5-alpha reductase enzyme
Direct stimulation of the growth of hair follicles
Increased blood flow to the hair follicles
Killing the fungi in the hair scalp

questions.solution:
This patient has androgenetic alopecia and was given finasteride and ketoconazole shampoo to decrease hair loss. Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication that has anti-androgen effects. These effects are due to two main mechanisms:

  • Ketoconazole inhibits the synthesis of testosterone by inhibiting the enzyme 17, 20 lyase, which is needed for the biosynthesis of testosterone
  • Ketoconazole also has competitive inhibition effects on androgen receptors.
Because of these anti-androgen effects, ketoconazole shampoo can be used to treat androgenetic alopecia (i.e. male pattern hair loss). It is often used with finasteride to produce greater effects and decrease hair loss.

Male patients taking ketoconazole to treat chronic fungal infections can experience side effects related to the anti-androgen effects of ketoconazole. These side effects include impotence, decreased libido, gynecomastia, oligospermia, and infertility.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased testosterone synthesis by inhibiting 17,20 lyase enzyme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone by inhibiting the 5-alpha reductase enzyme:
Incorrect: 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (e.g. finasteride) are effective in treating androgenetic alopecia. However, ketoconazole does not inhibit 5-alpha reductase enzymes.  
❌ Direct stimulation of the growth of hair follicles:
Incorrect: Ketoconazole has no direct effect on the growth of hair follicles.  
❌ Increased blood flow to the hair follicles:
Incorrect: Minoxidil is one of the treatment options for hair loss for various causes. It increases the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) mRNA, increasing the blood flow to the hair follicles, and promoting their growth. Ketoconazole has no such effect.  
❌ Killing the fungi in the hair scalp:
Incorrect: The use of ketoconazole in androgenetic alopecia is due to its anti-androgen effects, not antifungal effects.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the primary care office because of trouble with vision. Over the past two weeks, the patient has been experiencing intermittent episodes of blue-tinted vision, which resolve within a few hours each time. He woke up today with blurry vision in the right eye. There is no eye pain, conjunctival redness, or headache. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type II diabetes mellitus, and erectile dysfunction. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule
Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a transient, bluish visual discoloration, afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye, together with a history of erectile dysfunction, is most likely due to an adverse effect of a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor (e.g., sildenafil, vardenafil, tadalafil). These agents are first-line medical therapy for erectile dysfunction. They can also be used to treat pulmonary hypertension.    

PDE-5 is responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to smooth muscle relaxation (by enhancing NO activity). The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis.    

Therefore, PDE-5 inhibitors are usually indicated in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (enhances the erectile response to sexual stimulation), pulmonary hypertension (reduces pulmonary vascular resistance), and benign prostate hyperplasia (only tadalafil specifically). Common side effects include facial flushing, headache, dyspepsia, hearing loss, and hypotension (when used with nitrates or alpha-adrenergic blockers). Sildenafil cross-reacts with PDE-6 in the retina and can cause transient blue vision (as seen in this patient). Rarely, non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) can occur.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase :
Incorrect: Statins act by inhibiting hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase, leading to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling. Common side effects include hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal discomfort, and rash. The blue-tinted vision seen in this patient is not associated with stains. 
❌ Inhibition of mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase :
Incorrect: Metformin (used for diabetes mellitus) inhibits gluconeogenesis by inhibiting mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase. Side effects include weight loss, gastrointestinal upset, and possibly lactic acidosis. Blue-tinted vision is not associated with metformin. 
❌ Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule :
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitors (e.g. canagliflozin) act on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption of glucose. Common adverse effects include urinary tract infections, vulvovaginal candidiasis, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. They are not associated with visual disturbances. 
❌ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-3 in platelets :
Incorrect: Antiplatelet phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitors (e.g., cilostazol) inhibit platelet aggregation via increased cAMP in platelets. Common side effects include dizziness, headaches, palpitations, and gastrointestinal disturbance. They do not affect vision. 
✅ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the office because of erectile dysfunction. The patient reports a gradual decline in his ability to sustain an erection over the past several years. He used to wake up with erections, but no longer does. The patient retired from the army eight years ago. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral neuropathy, post-traumatic stress syndrome (PTSD), stable angina, and a prior myocardial infarction. Ophthalmologic evaluation six months ago revealed diabetic retinopathy, which was treated with photocoagulation. Current medications include metformin, escitalopram, aspirin, nitroglycerin, and atorvastatin. He drinks two to three drinks per week and has a 25 pack per year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased vibration sensation in both feet and a reduced pedal pulse on the left side. The patient requests a prescription of sildenafil. Which of the following is the most important consideration in prescribing sildenafil to this patient?
questions.solution:
Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors are first-line medications for the management of organic erectile dysfunction. Its use, however, is contraindicated in patients on nitrates (in this case, nitroglycerin).   

Nitrates are converted to nitric oxide, which promotes the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An increase in cGMP leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation. However, PDE-5, normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP, is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. This results in cGMP accumulation, leading to excessive vasodilation and profound hypotension when used with nitrates. Their use together is absolutely contraindicated.   

Option Analysis

✅ Current use of nitroglycerin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral neuropathy :
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy is not a contraindication to PDE-5 inhibitors. In fact, according to some studies, sildenafil has shown to decrease the symptoms of diabetic peripheral neuropathy. 
❌ Current use of atorvastatin :
Incorrect: There is no significant interaction between atorvastatin and PDE-5 inhibitor. 
❌ Diabetic retinopathy :
Incorrect: Although PDE-5 inhibitors are associated with temporary bluish visual discoloration due to the cross reactivity with PDE-6 inhibitors in the retina, this medication is not contraindicated in patients with diabetic retinopathy. 
❌ Current use of escitalopram :
Incorrect: Serotonin syndrome is an important consideration in prescribing a new serotonergic medication to a patient currently taking a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). However, sildenafil is not a serotonergic drug, so there is no concern regarding this patient’s use of escitalopram.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to involuntary loss of urine and chronic constipation. The leakage of urine occurs in coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavy weights. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient has had two forceps-assisted vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Pelvic examination reveals dribbling of urine when asked to cough and a mass at the vaginal opening. Post void residual urine is 40ml. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase or nitrites. She undergoes a paravaginal defect repair. During the procedure, a nerve passing through the obturator foramen is injured. The patient is most likely to develop sensory loss over which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient has stress urinary incontinence, constipation, and a mass per vaginum. She most likely has pelvic organ prolapse (POP) complicated by stress urinary incontinence. POP management involves pelvic floor exercises, mid-urethral sling placements, or surgery to repair the pervaginal defect.    

The obturator nerve is formed from the second, third, and fourth lumbar roots. It courses through the pelvis, posterior to the psoas major muscle, and the sacrum until it enters the obturator canal within the obturator foramen. In the thigh, it divides into anterior and posterior divisions. Both divisions supply motor innervation to the adductor muscles of the thigh. The anterior division carries sensory input from the hip joint and the medial thigh, while the posterior division carries input from the knee joint.    

The obturator nerve can be injured during surgeries that involve dissection in the obturator fossa. These include pelvic resection surgeries for endometriosis, pelvic lymph node dissection in gynecological malignancies, pervaginal defect repairs, and retropubic sling placements for pelvic organ prolapse. It can also be compressed by pelvic tumors or injured by pelvic trauma. A diagnosis of obturator neuropathy is primarily clinical. Symptoms include sensory loss over the medial aspect of the thigh and weakness in leg adduction.   

Option Analysis

✅ Medial thigh :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior thigh :
Incorrect: The cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve supplies the anterior thigh. It exits the pelvis and passes along the femoral canal. It does not traverse through the obturator canal.   
❌ Medial leg :
Incorrect: The medial leg is innervated by the cutaneous branches of the saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral nerve. It does not originate in the pelvis and is not likely to be damaged in this patient.   
❌ Medial foot :
Incorrect: The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the medial aspect of the foot. It is the branch of the common peroneal nerve and is unlikely to be injured in pelvic surgeries.   
❌ Posterior perineum :
Incorrect: The pudendal nerve provides sensory innervation to the perineum and the lower one-third of the vagina. It passes along the ischial spine and through the pudendal canal. It does not course through the obturator foramen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The pain began 6 hours ago and has become more severe over the last 2 hours. Past medical history includes seasonal depression and placement of a progestin-releasing IUD a month ago. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Bimanual examination reveals a tender, palpable left adnexal mass and visible IUD strings at the vaginal orifice. The urine pregnancy test is negative. The total leukocyte count is 8000/mm3. A transabdominal ultrasound reveals a hyperechoic adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. An explorative laparotomy is performed. The infundibulopelvic ligament is ligated during the procedure, and the pathological specimen is removed.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a tender adnexal mass with the decreased arterial flow. These findings are suggestive of ovarian torsion, which necessitates urgent intervention.    

Ovarian torsion is a common gynecological emergency among women of reproductive age, although it can occur in any age group. Clinical symptoms include sudden onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting with or without an adnexal mass. The most important risk factor for adnexal torsion is the presence of ovarian cysts or tumors, particularly those greater than 5 cm in size. Ovarian tumors are more common amongst women of reproductive age as most benign tumors (functional cyst, corpus luteum cysts) are associated with hormonal changes and ovulation induction therapy. Pathogenesis of ovarian torsion involves rotation of the ovary around the axis of its ligamentous attachment, the infundibulopelvic ligament. The presence of a large ovarian mass increases the likelihood of torsion.    

The infundibulopelvic ligament/suspensory ligament of the ovary attaches the superior pole of the ovary to the pelvic sidewall and contains the ovarian vessels. Rotation around its axis can impair the blood supply to the ovaries, which are detected as decreased blood flow on a doppler USG. Compression of the blood vessels impairs lymphatic and venous drainage and impedes arterial supply. Ovarian edema can progressively worsen and result in ischemia, local hemorrhage, and infarction complications.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ovarian torsion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ectopic pregnancy :
Incorrect: An extrauterine pregnancy is unlikely to cause abdominal pain as her last menstrual period was two weeks ago, and she has a negative pregnancy test.   
❌ Tubo-Ovarian abscess :
Incorrect: A tubo-ovarian abscess would cause fever and leukocytosis, neither of which are present in this patient. In addition, an abscess usually appears as an anechoic or hypoechoic fluid collection on ultrasound.   
❌ Uterine perforation :
Incorrect: Placement of IUDs can result in complications such as uterine perforation. It may present with severe, acute onset abdominal pain as seen in this patient. However, it is more likely to occur at the time of placement or immediately after and is unlikely in this case.   
❌ Endometriosis :
