Incorrect: Endometriosis classically presents with chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and dysmenorrhea. This patient's acute onset of symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic with flank pain. The pain began insidiously a month ago. She has not had nausea, vomiting, hematuria, dysuria, fever, or altered bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for a subtotal abdominal hysterectomy two months ago for uterine fibroids. She does not smoke, drink or consume alcohol.  Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the lower back. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

 

  
Reproduced from radiopedia.org   
Case courtesy of David Puyó

choices.text: Hydronephrosis due to a ureteral stone

questions.solution:
This patient developed flank pain of insidious onset, and a CT revealed dilated, renal calyces and a benign urinalysis. She most likely has a ureteral injury due to her recent abdominal hysterectomy.  The uterine and ovarian arteries provide blood supply to the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.    

Hysterectomies require ligation of the uterine artery in the broad ligament. Conditions like malignant ovarian tumors may require the ligation of the ovarian arteries in the infundibulopelvic ligament. The course of the ureter in the female pelvis is close to the uterine and ovarian vessels. Ligation of the uterine or ovarian vessels poses the risk of accidental ligation of the ureter.    

The ureter lies anterior to the internal iliac artery and then continues posteriorly to the ovary in the ovarian fossa along with the uterine vessels. At this point, the ureter is at risk of injury during an oophorectomy and should be appropriately identified before ligation of the ovarian vessels.    

The ureter then descends, crossing the ischial spine until it lies in the inferomedial portion of the broad ligament. In the broad ligament, the uterine artery is anterosuperior to the ureter (“=the bridge”) until it crosses the ureter in the lateral portion of the broad ligament. During a hysterectomy, the uterine artery is identified at the junction of the lower uterine segment and the cervix and ligated at the lateral border of the uterus. At this point, care should be taken to ensure that the clamps are placed on the uterine vessels and not the ureters.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Hydronephrosis due to ureteral injury :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Polycystic kidney disease :
Incorrect: Adult polycystic disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Patients may present with flank pain, hematuria, and hypertension. CT scan is likely to reveal multiple cysts instead of dilated renal calyces.    
❌ Hydronephrosis due to a ureteral stone :
Incorrect: A ureteric stone causes an acute onset of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria in addition to crystals on urine analysis. The insidious onset of this patient’s symptoms indicates the need for an alternative cause for her hydronephrosis.    
❌ Renal cell carcinoma :
Incorrect: RCC is suspected in patients with a history of smoking or those with a positive family history. Classically, symptoms include abdominal mass and hematuria, neither present in this patient.   
❌ Wilms tumor :
Incorrect: Wilms tumor is a common renal malignancy in children and classically presents with an abdominal mass. Considering this patient’s age, this diagnosis is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl comes to the clinic with a lump near her vagina. She first noticed the bump three days ago, making sitting and walking uncomfortable. The patient has not had a fever, vomiting, or dysuria. She plays soccer and is an active gymnast.  Past medical history includes schizophrenia and generalized anxiety disorder. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Focused physical examination reveals a nontender, cystic mass distending the right labia and obstructing the vaginal introitus. Total leukocyte count is 7,000/mm3. Which of the following is the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?  

 
By Medimage - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,  
Reproduced from Wikimedia commons

choices.text: Ductal obstruction of the paraurethral glands

questions.solution:
This patient has vaginal discomfort and a mass in the region of the Bartholin gland (also called the greater vestibular gland).  She most likely has a Bartholin’s cyst. Most cysts are asymptomatic and resolve on their own. Management with antibiotics and incision and drainage is only indicated if the cyst is infected.   Bartholin’s glands drain out to ducts present at the four o’clock and eight o’clock positions of the vaginal orifice. The gland's primary function is mucous secretion to increase vulvar and vaginal lubrication. If the ducts are obstructed at the orifice, mucous production accumulates, and a cystic swelling can form at the position of the ductal opening. This is known as a Bartholin’s cyst. If the fluid in the cyst gets infected, a Bartholin’s abscess develops.    

Bartholin’s cysts are asymptomatic and frequently present with a nontender, cystic swelling at the position of the Bartholin's duct in the posterior aspect of the vaginal orifice. Bartholin’s abscesses tend to be painful, erythematous, fluctuant, and tender. Patients are often febrile and complain of dyspareunia and difficulty walking and sitting down. Bartholin’s abscesses are treated with incision and drainage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ductal obstruction of Bartholin’s glands :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human papillomavirus infection :
Incorrect: HPV infection typically causes exophytic, sessile, or pedunculated growths in the perineum. It does not cause cystic masses.   
❌ Ductal obstruction of the paraurethral glands:
Incorrect: Skene’s glands are paraurethral glands that can form cysts due to ductal obstruction. The position of the cyst in this patient is not consistent with a Skene’s gland cyst, which forms adjacent to the urethral meatus. Symptoms of a Skene’s gland cyst include painful urination and urinary tract infections.  
❌ Hematoma due to local trauma :
Incorrect: A hematoma would present with pain, erythema, and swelling within 24 hours of injury. This patient does not have a history of trauma to her genital region.   
❌ Poxvirus infection  :
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus and classically presents as small, painless, umbilicated papules distributed in the genital region. Cystic lesions are not common.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician’s clinic due to involuntary loss of urine and chronic constipation. She has leakage of urine with coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavyweights. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a hysterectomy (six months ago) for uterine fibroids. The patient had two forceps-assisted vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Pelvic examination reveals dribbling of urine when the patient coughs. Post void residual urine is 40 ml. Urinalysis is negative for leukocyte esterase or nitrites. Which of the following best describes the anatomic site of pathology responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of recent hysterectomy and two forceps assisted vaginal deliveries presents with urinary incontinence that worsens with maneuvers that increase intraabdominal pressure. She most likely has stress urinary incontinence secondary to pelvic organ prolapse. This condition results in the herniation of pelvic organs, including the bladder, rectum, or uterus, into the vaginal canal. Symptoms include a sensation of a mass in the perineum, urinary symptoms (stress incontinence, difficulty voiding, and retention), and bowel dysfunction (constipation or fecal incontinence). The perineal body is often implicated in pelvic organ prolapse.    

The perineal body is a fibromuscular node formed from the convergence of muscles of the perineum, including the levator ani, bulbospongiosus, superficial and deep transverse perinei, external anal sphincter, and the longitudinal muscle coat of the anal canal. It is located centrally in the perineum between the lower part of the vagina and the anal canal. It may be damaged during labor and delivery or abdominal surgeries such as hysterectomy.    

Specific risk factors that lead to perineal injury during childbirth include nulliparity, macrosomia (weight >3kg), shoulder dystocia, instrumental delivery, and precipitate labor. The perineal body remains important for supporting female pelvic organs, specifically the posterior wall of the vagina. A complication that arises from inadequate repairs of perineal body injury (second-degree perineal tears) is pelvic organ prolapse and urinary stress incontinence.    

Treatment of pelvic organ prolapse includes weight loss, kegel’s exercises, and placement of a vaginal pessary or surgery. Kegel exercises refer to pelvic exercises that strengthen the pelvic floor muscles.  



Option Analysis

✅ Perineal body    :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Obturator nerve    :
Incorrect: Obturator neuralgia usually occurs secondary to pelvic surgery, trauma, or tumors and presents with weakness in hip adduction and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the thigh. Urinary incontinence is not observed.   
❌ Pudendal nerve  :
Incorrect: Pudendal neuralgia can occur as a complication of pelvic surgery or obstructed labor. Injury to this nerve is clinically characterized by pain and paraesthesias involving the sensory distribution of the pudendal nerve, which includes the perineum and the lower third of the vagina. Urinary incontinence and constipation are not commonly observed with this condition.   
❌ Vaginal wall:
Incorrect: Vesicovaginal fistulas are aberrant communications between the genital tract and bladder that often form a pelvic complication surgery. They are characterized by continuous involuntary dribbling of urine without exacerbation by coughing, sneezing, or lifting heavy objects. Examination often reveals a vaginal wall defect or pooling of urine in the vault.   
❌ Bladder wall :
Incorrect: A urinary tract infection (UTI) can cause polyuria due to incomplete bladder emptying; however, UTIs typically present with dysuria and positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites on urinalysis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic for follow-up after a radical abdominal hysterectomy for endometrial cancer a month ago. Over the last two weeks, the patient has noticed continuous urine leakage that soaks two to three pads a day. She has not experienced difficulty passing urine, urinary retention, or incomplete emptying. Past medical history includes depression treated with venlafaxine and escitalopram, and multiple sclerosis. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. The vagina has a scant clear discharge. Pelvic examination reveals a granular mass on the anterior vaginal wall. Post void residual urine is 50 ml. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aberrant connection between the bladder and vagina
Overflow incontinence from bladder outlet obstruction

questions.solution:
This patient has continuous leakage of urine, a vaginal wall defect, and recently underwent a radical abdominal hysterectomy. She most likely has a genitourinary fistula.    

A fistula is a pathological communication formed between two epithelialized surfaces. Genitourinary fistulas form between the urinary and genital tracts. The transmission can occur between the bladder (vesicovaginal) or urethra (urethrovaginal) and the genital tract. Fistulas in the genital tract can result from obstetric trauma to the vaginal wall (instrumental vaginal delivery), ischemia to the vaginal wall from prolonged and obstructed labor, malignancies of the genital tract, operative injuries (eg, abdominal hysterectomies), or radiation therapy.    

In developing countries, the most common cause of fistulas is obstetric trauma. Prolonged compression of the bladder wall between the fetal head and symphysis pubis can cause ischemia, necrosis, and sloughing to form a fistula.    

Vesicovaginal fistulas are aberrant communications between the bladder and the vagina. Clinical symptoms include the continuous passage of urine from the vaginal opening. A visible vaginal defect and pooling of clear fluid in the vagina are noted on clinical examination. Rectovaginal fistulas are pathologic communications formed between the lower gastrointestinal tract and the vagina and most commonly result from obstetric trauma, including inadequately healed perineal lacerations. They can also occur as a complication from Crohn’s disease. Clinical symptoms include malodorous, brown vaginal discharge and a posterior vaginal defect noted on physical examination.   Treatment involves surgical repair.   

Option Analysis

✅ Aberrant connection between the bladder and vagina :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neurogenic bladder dysfunction :
Incorrect: Diabetic neuropathy can cause neurogenic bladder dysfunction and result in incomplete bladder emptying and overflow incontinence. Most patients will have a high void residual urine volume. This patient’s post-void urine volume is normal.  
❌ Overflow incontinence from bladder outlet obstruction :
Incorrect: Patients with bladder outlet obstruction have high post-void residual urine and a distended bladder on abdominal examination. This patient’s post-void urine volume is normal.   
❌ Postmenopausal hypoestrogenism :
Incorrect: Estrogen deficiency after menopause can result in a genitourinary syndrome of menopause which can cause vulvovaginal atrophy, recurrent urinary infections, and incontinence. However, incontinence is usually intermittent and not continuous.   
❌ Urethral hypermobility :
Incorrect: Stress urinary incontinence is caused by urethral hypermobility and results in intermittent loss of urine, particularly with increased abdominal pressure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old nulliparous woman presents to the office for evaluation of vaginal spotting for 2 weeks. She has not experienced any associated pain or discharge. Menarche was at age 10, and she had a regular menstrual cycle until menopause at the age of 52. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for 20 years treated with metformin. She is on continuous estrogen replacement therapy for postmenopausal hot flashes for the last 3 years. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her maternal grandmother. BMI is 33.5 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows labial fullness, moist vaginal mucosa and a normal-sized uterus. Endometrial biopsy of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The histopathologic finding of glandular architecture admixed with solid areas together with postmenopausal bleeding in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of type I (endometrioid) endometrial carcinoma.  

Endometrial carcinoma is the most common gynecological cancer in the developed countries. It is a pathological process that results from an increase in estrogen levels without accompanying increase in progesterone. A stepwise acquisition of genetic mutations is involved in the development of this carcinoma, including mutations in PTEN and KRAS and microsatellite instability. PTEN inactivation is the most common and is observed in early carcinogenesis. Major risk factors include obesity, early menarche, late menopause, unopposed estrogen therapy (ET), nulliparity, chronic anovulation and hereditary syndromes (e.g. Lynch syndrome). It clinically presents as unexplained dysfunctional uterine bleeding in pre or post-menopausal women. Ultrasound can be obtained in post-menopausal patients, which reveals endometrial thickness >5mm. However, endometrial biopsy is diagnostic and shows atypical glandular architecture with or without intervening solid areas.  

Option Analysis

❌  Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This answer is an endometrial sample representing the secretory phase of menstrual cycle, where the endometrial glands become large and coiled under the effect of progesterone. This patient has passed menopause.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons:
Incorrect: This answer is a sample of uterine myometrium showing bundles of spindle-shaped cells with uniform size and shape indicative of a leiomyoma.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons:
Incorrect: This histologic image shows all three germ layers including mesoderm (top left), endoderm (center bottom) and ectoderm (right), typically seen in mature teratoma. Most women with teratomas are asymptomatic; however, symptoms depend upon the size of the mass. Abdominal fullness is a common feeling, with ovarian torsion as a common complication.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This answer is a typical histologic picture of type II (serous) endometrial carcinoma showing a complex papillary architecture with psammoma bodies and nuclear atypia (high nucleus-to-cytoplasmic ratio, hyperchromasia and prominent nucleoli). It is less common and usually occurs after the age of 65 in the setting of endometrial atrophy.
✅  Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, presents to the emergency department with complaints of lower abdominal pain and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She gave birth to a healthy female newborn 2 days ago. Vaginal delivery was converted into emergency cesarean section due to obstructed labor, and the placenta was removed manually. Past medical history is significant for pre-gestational diabetes mellitus type II as well as Neisseria gonorrhoeae cervicitis when the patient was 19, for which she was treated appropriately. Temperature is 101.4°F (38.5 °C), pulse is 100/minute, respirations are 19/minute, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. BMI is 33 kg/m2. On physical examination, there is mild peri-incisional tenderness, minimal discharge at the surgical site, and no erythema or edema around the incision site. Foul-smelling greenish-yellow lochia is observed in the vaginal vault. Bimanual examination shows cervical motion and uterine tenderness. Complete blood profile shows hemoglobin of 12 g/dL and leukocyte count of 18,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of lower abdominal pain, foul-smelling purulent vaginal discharge, high-grade fever and uterine tenderness are consistent with the diagnosis of endometritis. 

Endometritis is a polymicrobial infection of the endometrium. Most of the organisms are part of the endogenous cervicovaginal flora that travel upwards during labor and delivery. Route of delivery is the most important risk factor in the development of postpartum endometritis. Up to 30% of cases occur after cesarean deliveries (especially those performed after the onset of labor or rupture of membranes) as compared to <3% after vaginal birth. Other proposed risk factors include prolonged rupture of membranes, retained products of conception following delivery, uncontrolled maternal diabetes and heavy vaginal colonization by E. coli. However, none is as significant as the route of delivery.    

Endometritis can be either acute or chronic. Acute endometritis typically presents with symptoms like fever, vaginal discharge and/or bleeding, lower abdominal pain, dysuria and cervical motion and uterine tenderness, whereas chronic endometritis is usually asymptomatic with normal physical examination. Presence of neutrophils on microscopic examination is the hallmark of acute endometritis, whereas as plasma cells are seen in chronic endometritis. Combination of clindamycin and gentamicin is the treatment of choice for these patients.  



Option Analysis

❌ Surgical site infection:
Incorrect: Although this patient has systemic signs of an infection, and surgical site infection is a likely cause after this patient’s cesarean delivery, it is unlikely given the physical examination findings showing minimal incision-site erythema, edema, or discharge. 
❌ Pyelonephritis:
Incorrect: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever (>100.4°F), chills, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and lower urinary tract symptoms. Pyuria and/or a positive urine culture supports the diagnosis. This patient has no costovertebral tenderness or urinary complaints, and the uterine tenderness supports a different diagnosis. 
✅ Endometritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis:
Incorrect: Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (SPT) is a rare condition that occurs in the setting of pelvic vein damage, venous stasis, and hypercoagulability, often following delivery or surgery. SPT should be suspected if there is a persistent fever in the weeks following delivery despite antibiotic therapy. Given this patient’s uterine tenderness in the days following cesarean delivery, however, another diagnosis is more likely. 
❌ Pelvic inflammatory disease:
Incorrect: Pelvic inflammatory disease occurs secondary to a vaginal or cervical infection, typically caused by N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.  Common presentations include acute pelvic pain, cervical motion tenderness, vaginal discharge, fever, dyspareunia, and leukocytosis. Although this patient has vaginal discharge and cervical motion tenderness, the recent cesarean delivery and uterine tenderness support a different diagnosis.
